title: Even as Trump Targets Boats in Strikes, Coast Guard Continues Anti-Drug Operations
summary: Cutters are still stopping smugglers and seizing drugs, but the prosecutions of go-fast boat crews are dwindling in a realignment of federal resources.

title: A Timeline of Key Events in the Trump Administration’s Pursuit of Abrego Garcia
summary: In its parallel efforts to prosecute Mr. Abrego Garcia and to re-expel him from the country, the Justice Department has spent countless hours and untold sums of money pursuing a single immigrant.

title: An Intense White House Response From a Single Viral Video
summary: A video purporting to expose extensive fraud at child care centers in Minnesota shows the relationship between the Trump administration and self-described citizen journalists.

title: 6 Takeaways on the Unwinding U.S.-Ukraine Alliance
summary: A Times investigation reveals the inside story of the Trump administration’s chaotic push for a peace deal and its erratic role in the war.

title: In New Year’s Speech to Russia, Putin Says Little About Ukraine War or Peace Talks With US
summary: The Kremlin leader kept his speech short, spoke only briefly about the fighting in Ukraine, and did not mention U.S.-mediated talks on ending the war.

title: For Zohran Mamdani, a Crowning Moment, With Challenges Looming
summary: Mr. Mamdani will become mayor of New York City on Thursday, carrying the hopes of the left, Muslims and younger voters as he looks to improve affordability.

title: Mamdani Will Be First N.Y.C. Mayor to Use the Quran at His Swearing-In
summary: Zohran Mamdani, New York City’s first Muslim mayor, will use two family Qurans and one that belonged to the writer Arturo Schomburg at his two swearing-in ceremonies.

title: The Keys to the City of New York Are Made in New Jersey
summary: Mayor Eric Adams has handed out dozens of ceremonial golden keys during his single term. Since 2023, they have come from across the Hudson River.

title: These Inmates Died After Beatings by New York Prison Guards. No One Raised an Alarm.
summary: Two brutal killings, less than three months apart, in New York State’s prison system raised troubling questions: Had other inmates met similar fates?

title: One Lawyer’s Standoff With Trump’s Deportation Machine
summary: Mahsa Khanbabai’s client, a graduate student, had been whisked away by masked agents and held in lockup for weeks. Would a court free her — and would the government let her go?

title: The Top Movies of 2025, According to Times Readers: ‘Marty Supreme’ and More
summary: We asked you to vote on the best films of the year. The results ranged from big box office hits to small art-house indies.

title: Women Directed Fewer Box Office Hits in 2025, Report Finds
summary: The number of female filmmakers dropped to 8.1 percent this year from 13.4 percent in 2024, according to a study from the University of Southern California.

title: Will the A.I. Boom Continue to Drive Up Stocks in 2026?
summary: The boom in artificial intelligence was the biggest driver of gains in the stock market. That could pose a risk in 2026.

title: Tatiana Schlossberg Submitted a Heartbreaking Essay to The New Yorker on Her Cancer Diagnosis, Fully Formed
summary: When Tatiana Schlossberg submitted an essay to The New Yorker, it had not been assigned or even expected. It was accepted immediately and barely edited.

title: Tatiana Schlossberg, Kennedy Daughter Who Wrote of Her Cancer, Dies at 35
summary: An environmental journalist and child of Caroline Kennedy, she wrote of her struggle with leukemia in The New Yorker in November, drawing worldwide sympathy.

title: He Is Being Sued in the U.S. for Human Rights Abuses. He Could be Deported First.
summary: Rafael Quero Silva faces a lawsuit brought by five people who say he oversaw their abuse and mistreatment as a military officer in Venezuela. But he could be deported before the case is heard.

title: A Farewell Ride With the MetroCard, on Every Transit Line That Uses It
summary: Two Times journalists joined Miles Taylor, a YouTuber and transport enthusiast, on a daylong journey across New York City area buses and trains before sale of the card ends on Dec. 31.

title: ‘Stranger Things’ Cast Looks Back on the Show and How It Shaped Them
summary: The first episodes of the final season just premiered on Netflix. In interviews, the young stars looked back on the show and how it shaped them.

title: ‘Stranger Things’ Creators Break Down Their Latest Influences
summary: With a new batch of episodes arriving on Christmas Day, Matt and Ross Duffer discuss the sometimes obscure movie and video game references in the final season so far.

title: The 2025 Politics Yearbook: Most Likely to Be Extreme and Chaotic
summary: How much more chaotic could a second Trump term be? 2025 did not disappoint.

title: There Is a Way Out of This Mess
summary: A second Gilded Age, a single solution.

title: Manhattan Man, 80, Faces Homicide Charge After Sidewalk Shoving
summary: Dana Escoffier was indicted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide in the death of Dean Whetzel, 82, a neighbor whom he had known for decades.

title: From A.I. to Immigration, These New State Laws Will Take Effect in 2026
summary: States across the country have also passed new rules around cellphone usage for minors, medically assisted death and gender-related care.

title: Thieves Make Off With Millions in German Bank Heist
summary: The robbers stole valuables with an insured value of at least $36 million from a bank in Gelsenkirchen, western Germany.

title: Isiah Whitlock Jr., Scene-Stealing Character Actor in ‘The Wire,’ Dies at 71
summary: In one of his most enduring roles, he played a corrupt state senator known for his ability to fashion an expletive into an outstretched catchphrase.
